Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: CC relies on OP_RETURN data that is public

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: zaddr metadata is private, can't be verified by others, i.e. the rest of the network doesn't know what the contract is, etc...

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: *but* I believe we have solved the notarization issue

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the new rule for `ac_private=1` should be "Only coinbase *or* amount=0 transparent outputs are allowed"

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: my patch above does that, trying to verify it actually works correctly

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: what this means, is that you must use z_sendmany

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: you can't do a taddr -> taddr amount=0 xtn, that is still illegal

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that leaks too much metadata

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: so first, the person must move to a zaddr, then if that person, a NN, wants to notarize, they can make an amount=0 xtn

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: via z_sendmany

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @grewalsatinder i think this opens the door for a 2 stage kind of approach to making stuff work

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: Interesting

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: like, we store a bit of info in OP_RETURN, but other stuff in private zaddr metadata (which there is a lot more of, per xtn)

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: that would be a James question

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: Thanks for doing what u doing mate :-)

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: ðŸ‘

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's just fun, I guess

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: If both notarization and CC solves for private chain I would like to turn MESH to private only.

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: CC for ac_private means implement new contracts from the ground up, new internals, but perhaps they can build on the ones we have. Extensions that can unlock rewards to zaddrs and stuff like that

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: Yes OK with new cc contracts. I wish to have private only chains to be CC capable

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i agree, that would be very interesting

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: when Sapling turns on in Zcash 2.x, we will see real benchmarks of how much faster shielding has gotten

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: True, and recreating the existing cc on private only chain would be I guess a on field exercise like for a new dev like me

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i wouldn't call it trivial ðŸ˜ƒ

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: but at least you have a well-worn path to follow from James's 4 initial contracts

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: Yea... At least I have good help here... from the ground up...

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: just did my first PIRATE z_shieldcoinbase

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: maybe that wasn't a good idea since the chain is stuck

Author: grewalsatinder#9653
Content: Haha

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: yeah buddy

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: all this stuff reminded me very much of Hushlist

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: the infamous memo field, 512 bytes of joy

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i am thinking of CC contracts where basic info is stored publicy in OP_RETURN, the very atoms of how the contract works, but the actual "meat" of the contract, which addresses get paid, how much, etc... are stored in the memo field, encrypted, viewable only to those that have the private key to the address that received that memo

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: viewing keys probably could be used to help implement CC with some data in zaddr memo fields

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Chain isnt stuck anymore

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: I fixed it, slowly pulled hash off...

Author: blackjok3r#3181
Content: Its got 8 1080's on it atm and my rig at home

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it's just brutally slow with Sprout, hopefully Sapling makes stuff reasonable. Not even fast, just reasonable

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I embedded a 27KB image of the Hush logo into the Hush blockchain, in one transaction (54 addrs x 512 bytes) and it took *45 minutes* to make the transaction, before getting sent to the network

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: even just 45 seconds of pegging a CPU, to send to one output, is kind of shitty

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: Sapling has 2way viewing keys, they changed everything, I think for the better. But also it's a bit more complex

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: 2way viewing keys probably open up the door for atomic swaps and CC's that have some data hidden

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: if the algorithm of your smart contract is public, but the addresses that it pays out to are not, isn't that pretty good ? I think it solves the use case most people are after

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @blackjok3r thanks for unsticking it

Content: also, they want to charge $200 every time they need to upgrade your coin

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: it doesn't make financial sense for an exchange to do shielded xtns, and it might not even be technically feasible for the load of transactions they need to break even

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: maybe if they charged large fees, but that just drives users to use transparent addresses it seems

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content:
```(myhush02)(~/git/komodo/src pirate $%= )$ ./fiat/pirate z_sendmany zcQjP16nDtkAyUgqeCmTKNnTyuH9ZPh5MYZzWYY1rFYT2mJBn7sNGZ4qcJZjih5Z6KJZiwzUKdNEDYSq3m1L6mMMC6i7mzf "[{\"address\":\"$TADDR\",\"amount\":1.0}]" 1 0.0
error code: -5
error message:
cant use transparent addresses with non-zero amounts in private chain
(myhush02)(~/git/komodo/src pirate $%= )$ ./fiat/pirate z_sendmany zcQjP16nDtkAyUgqeCmTKNnTyuH9ZPh5MYZzWYY1rFYT2mJBn7sNGZ4qcJZjih5Z6KJZiwzUKdNEDYSq3m1L6mMMC6i7mzf "[{\"address\":\"$TADDR\",\"amount\":0.0}]" 1 0.0
opid-02ae319e-c251-461f-a355-0b8581b4d44e```

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: first try was with non-zero amount, failed as it should, 2nd passes with amount=0

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: http://pirate.explorer.dexstats.info/tx/38bcdb30af936861731c1ba02b836849cfaac93f389329751ccd33465d3d04e6

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: i think this points out an explorer bug (sorry if I sound like a broken record) where it doesn't even show the output correctly

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I guess pure transparent outputs have their address rendered, but transparent outputs of joinsplits are different

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: I am not sure if notarization code can use these kinds of outputs, @jl777c will have to weigh in, if this will allow notarizing PIRATE

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: @jl777c https://github.com/jl777/komodo/pull/857

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: James will have to weigh in on whether that will help us notarize

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: a transparent output from a JoinSplit isn't quite *exactly* the same as a pure taddr -> taddr output, which has OP_RETURN data. If it is, then we are very lucky, my guess is that it's not

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: so we might have to modify how notarization works a bit. But it no longer seems impossible, so that is good

Author: dukeleto#7326
Content: this was all sparked by @Alright's trick to use CC rpcs to make a transparent output, nice sneaky trick ye salty dog

Content: notarization is a multisig transaction
